Key Match Events: Pakistan has beaten New Zealand by seven wickets to reach a third T20 World Cup final.
A century stand for the first wicket from Babar Azam (53) and Muhammad Rizwan (57) gave Pakistan a perfect platform from which to reach their target.

Finn Allen (4) endured an eventful opening three balls, smashing a four down the ground, getting given out LBW — which he managed to overturn on review thanks to a thick inside edge — before Shaheen Shah Afridi completed the job with a gorgeous inswinger next ball.
Devon Conway (21) was run out by Shadab Khan.
Glenn Phillips (6) was caught off his own bowling by Mohammad Nawaz.
Williamson and Mitchell put on 68 for the fourth wicket before the New Zealand skipper was bowled by a brilliant Afridi slower ball.
Boult struck twice for the Kiwis, dismissing both Rizwan and Azam.
Haris fireworks put paid to any hopes of a New Zealand revival.
Pakistan will now face the winner of Thursday's semifinal between England or India at the MCG.
It is Pakistan's first World Cup final since 2009, when they beat Sri Lanka in the final at Lord's.
Pre-Game Insights: New Zealand would have felt confident coming into the game — on the same strip just a couple of weeks earlier, they thrashed Australia to get their tournament off to a superb start.
Even by winning the toss the omens were in their favour — five of the six teams who batted first at the SCG in T20 matches had won.
Post-Match Reflections: Babar Azam credits his bowlers and says the team performed very well in the last three matches and then today.
Kane Williamson expressed disappointment, stating that it is very disappointing not to make Pakistan work a little bit more for that.
Muhammad Rizwan wins player of the match and expressed his luck in scoring his first half-century of the tournament in the semi-final.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The vast majority of the 36,443 in attendance at the SCG were supporting Pakistan.
Pakistan will now take on England or India at the MCG, the same venue where they won the ODI World Cup in 1992.
New Zealand has won only three out of 12 appearances in a World Cup semifinal across 50- and 20-over competitions.
